comment.author: 22867700@N04
comment._content: Unbelievable shot. This guy was good, and man, did he get around!

comment.author: 25356247@N00
comment._content: The locomotive in this picture is number 5000, a 2-10-4 built in 1930 by Baldwin. It is now preserved in Amarillo, Texas. There's more information at the Wikipedia page about this locomotive.

comment.author: 8623220@N02
comment._content: Very interesting information! Thanks for your interest in the collection.

comment.author: 13893317@N06
comment._content: Yes, that's Madame Queen, an experimental 2-10-4 that gave rise to the 5001 class of 1938 and the 5011 class of 1944.  The 5011 class were the last steam engines built for the Santa Fe and ran in helper service until 1957 in Abo Canyon, east of Belen.  This passing siding is still protected by Automatic Block Signals using upper quadrant semaphores in this photo.  Before WWII was over, heavy freight traffic caused this division to get Centralized Traffic Control with searchlight signals.

comment.author: 21060829@N05
comment._content: Hi, I'm an admin for a group called Railroad Semaphore Signals of the World, and we'd love to have this added to the group!

comment.author: 57829293@N04
comment._content: Is this a 4x5 or an 8x10 Kodachrome?

comment.author: 57829293@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/13893317@N06]  Make those signals  Union Switch & Signal Style "T-2" Semaphores introduced in 1912. These are the very last of all semaphore types in use on any U.S. Railroad.  The handful remaining are only found on the former AT&SF Railway, north of Albuquerque, through Las Vegas (N.M.) and on towards Raton Pass.
